awd_titl_txt: Computer Science Connections: Using Data Science to Broaden Participation in Middle School
awd_abstract_narration:
This award is funded in whole or in part under the American Rescue Plan Act of 2021 (Public Law 117-2). This project will help middle school computer science (CS) students connect more deeply with CS content and promote inclusion and equitable participation in CS classrooms through data science. Data science is a new field that applies computer science and statistics to data sets with the goal of extracting useful information. Data science skills have become necessary to make sense of complex social and scientific problems. Data science has mainly been taught in graduate and undergraduate programs, but more and more groups are aiming to teach data science in elementary, middle, and high school. Data science instruction can give computer science students the opportunity to solve authentic and socially relevant problems, increasing interest and motivation, particularly for learners who are members of historically underrepresented groups in science, technology, engineering, and mathematics (STEM). Authentic and socially relevant problems also provide opportunities for students to engage in classroom discourse, a strategy that has demonstrated benefits for English learners in mathematics classes.

Computer Science Connections is a researcher-practitioner partnership (RPP) between WestEd and the Oakland Unified School District (OUSD). The partnership will use a design research approach to modify the data science content within OUSD’s middle school computer science curriculum to include more socially relevant problems and to incorporate classroom discourse strategies. The OUSD team will design the new data science unit and establish a professional learning community (PLC) to prepare teachers to teach it. Using a combination of focus groups, surveys, and observations, the WestEd team will conduct research on teachers’ and students’ perceptions of data science and how it is currently taught in OUSD middle schools.  The team will also evaluate the effectiveness of the new data science unit in OUSD CS classrooms and how well the data science PLC prepares teachers to teach data science. The success of the partnership will be evaluated by an external advisory panel with expertise in computer science education, math education, data science education, and teacher professional development. The RPP will provide information to the field on the successes and challenges of engaging in this work and a program that is evidence-based through rigorous efficacy research. This project is funded by the CS for All: Research and RPPs program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
This project was a research-practice partnership between WestEd, a nonpartisan education research, development, and service agency, and the Oakland Unified School District (OUSD). At the start of this project, OUSD's middle school computer science (CS) classes, which used Code.org's CS Discoveries curriculum, were spending very little time teaching Unit 5: Data and Society because both teachers and students struggled to see the connection to the programming and game design elements present in the other units in the course.

We used two key strategies to increase teachers' and students' engagement with the Data and Society unit. The first was to center the unit around a theme of "using data to make school better." Students worked with a variety of school-themed data sets and problems like reducing cafeteria waste and planning a school-wide party. We also introduced students to the Common Online Data Analysis Platform (CODAP), developed by the Concord Consortium, to support students in data analysis and data visualization using computational tools.

The second key strategy was to introduce the use of language routines, which we adapted from the work of Zweirs and colleagues at the Stanford Center for Assessment, Learning, and Equity (SCALE). Computer science is a discipline that places great demands on students' language skills. The language routines are structured approaches to initiating and facilitating student talk. During these routines, students make sense of problems and ideas and share their thinking with others.

For example, to scaffold students' making sense of unfamiliar data, we created a "Three Reads of Data" routine based on the "Three Reads" language routine developed by SCALE. Every time students saw a new dataset, they used this new routine. The routine has three parts:

Read #1: (Shared Reading) Discuss: What is this situation about?

  • This data is from...

  • I know that...

  • A pattern I see is...

  • The data is organized...

Read #2: (Individual, Pairs, or Shared Reading) Discuss: What quantities do you notice?

  • There are ___ cases

  • The sample size is ___

  • There are ___ attributes

  • The range is…

Read #3: (Individual, Pairs, or Shared Reading) Discuss: What questions can I answer using this data?

  • A question I could answer is...

  • This data could show...

We created a student-facing language routine card with the above prompts to explain the purpose of each read and provide students with the sentence starters to promote their use of academic language. The sentence starters are a critical scaffold for encouraging diverse students to engage in classroom discourse. When students are encouraged to talk more in class and share their ideas and solutions with others, they feel their ideas are more valued. Classroom discourse helps build student agency and motivation and creates a classroom community of learners. 

During this project, we iteratively revised the Data and Society unit to expand the content and implement our two strategies. The final unit contains ten lessons:

 1. What is data science? Learn what data science is and why it's important, including who does data science, where data comes from, and how data is used

2. Making sense of data. Interpret information presented in a spreadsheet

3. Visualizing data, part 1: One-variable data. Use CODAP to create a data visualization and then use it to describe the data (i.e., shape, distribution, measures of center)

4. Understanding survey data. Describe how different types of questions (i.e., closed vs. open questions) lead to different types of data (i.e., numerical, categorical, open text) and discuss the tradeoffs of each.

5. Cleaning data. Clean and organize survey results and describe the tradeoffs involved when cleaning a data set.

6. Visualizing data, part 2: Two or more variables. Use CODAP to create a visualization of two or more variables from a data set and then use it to describe the data.

7. Telling the story of data. Choose between different visualizations of the same data set and select the one that best answers a data question.

8. Gathering useful samples. Explain how well a given data set can answer a question, considering factors such as size, source, question type, and sampling.

9. Let's put it to work, part 1: Answering your own data question. Identify a data question and create a visualization of at least two variables from a data set to answer the questions.

10. Let's put it to work, part 2: Communicating your data. Use the data visualization to describe the data, answer the data question, and reflect on the choices made as a data scientist.
